facts.text: Election held on March 8, 1957, for Mysore State Legislative Assembly, Harihar constituency.

Nomination papers of Hanumanthappa (Patel), Siddappa (Patel), and Guru Rao (Shanbhog) rejected by Returning Officer as holders of offices of profit under Mysore Government, disqualified under Art. 191.
Two candidates left, appellant declared elected with larger number of votes.

Six electors of Harihar constituency filed election petition under s.100(1)(c) of Representation of the People Act, 1951, alleging improper rejection of nominations, seeking declaration that appellant's election void.
Election Tribunal dismissed petition on September 10, 1957, holding Patels and Shanbhogs hold offices of profit under Mysore Village Offices Act, 1908, with considerable remuneration.
Petitioners appealed to Mysore High Court, which allowed appeal on February 26, 1958, held offices not under Government, declared appellant's election void.
Appeal to Supreme Court with certificate under Art. 133(1)(c); one petitioner dead, five respondents.
Undisputed: Hanumanthappa and Siddappa held offices of Patels with lands allotted and cash allowances; Guru Rao Shanbhog with cash remuneration; all have specific duties and are holders of offices.

legal_issues.text: Whether Patels and Shanbhogs are holders of offices of profit under the Mysore Government and thus disqualified under Art. 191 of the Constitution for being chosen as members of the Legislative Assembly.

petitioner_arguments.text: Patels and Shanbhogs hold office by reason of Government appointment, even if no option in some cases; office held under Government as appointment perfects right; no one else under whom held; dismissal power under s.7 does not negate; remuneration from Government funds; duties under Government control.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Mysore Village Offices Act, 1908 (ss.6,7,8,11); Art. 310 Constitution

respondent_arguments.text: Offices hereditary under customary law, held under village community as agents/liaisons; Government appoints only if no hereditary holder; Act consolidates without altering hereditary right; not under Government; small remuneration; no direct payment; s.11 right to sue; minor successor provision.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Mysore Land Revenue Code, 1888; Mysore Village Offices Act, 1908; Mangal Sain v. State of Punjab

court_reasoning.text: Mysore Village Offices Act, 1908 governs; recognizes limited hereditary right but appointment by Government required to hold office (s.8); heir not appointed if ineligible (s.8(1)); even if mandatory, appointment by Government makes office under it; no corporate village community.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Appointment by Government perfects right to office.

court_reasoning.text: Dismissal under s.7; not at pleasure but statute can limit (Gould v. Stuart); does not negate holding under Government.
Remuneration: lands allotted, cash from revenue collected (deemed Government payment per rules); duties fixed under Government control/supervision.
Mangal Sain distinguished: municipality exists there, not here.

holdings.text: Patels and Shanbhogs hold offices of profit under the Mysore Government.

precedents_cited.case_name: Mangal Sain v. State of Punjab
precedents_cited.relevance: Appointment/dismissal by Government does not make officeholder servant if held under another body like municipality.
Statute can prevent dismissal at Government's pleasure without negating service under Government.

precedents_cited.case_name: R. Venkata Rao v. Secretary of State for India
precedents_cited.relevance: Refers to Gould v. Stuart on statutory limits to dismissal.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Disqualification for office of profit; certificate for appeal; pleasure doctrine for dismissal.

statutes_cited.name: Representation of the People Act, 1951
statutes_cited.relevance: Ground for declaring election void: improper rejection of nomination.

statutes_cited.name: Mysore Village Offices Act, 1908
statutes_cited.relevance: Governs village offices, appointments, hereditary rights, eligibility, dismissal.

statutes_cited.name: Mysore Land Revenue Code, 1888
statutes_cited.relevance: Government appoints only if no hereditary Patel/Shanbhog.

outcome.summary: Appeal allowed; High Court judgment and order set aside; Election Tribunal's order restored; election petition dismissed. Nomination rejections proper.

key_quotes.text: The appointment being by the Government, the office to which it is made must be held under it for there is no one else under whom it can be held.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core reasoning on why office under Government despite hereditary aspects.

key_quotes.text: All these clearly establish that Patels and Shanbhogs hold offices of profit under the Government.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Concluding holding on the main issue.
